content.value_statement: Developing Claude Code plugins requires understanding the correct directory structure, manifest configuration, and component organization patterns. This skill provides comprehensive guidance on plugin architecture so you can build maintainable plugins that follow Claude Code conventions.
actual_capabilities: Explains the standard plugin directory structure with required and optional directories
Documents plugin.json manifest fields with examples for minimal and complete configurations
Describes component organization patterns for commands, agents, skills, and hooks
Details the auto-discovery mechanism for automatic component loading
Provides guidance on using ${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT} for portable path references
Includes complete example plugins from minimal to advanced patterns
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files on your system
Does not provide interactive plugin scaffolding or code generation
Does not install or manage plugins in your Claude Code environment
Focuses on architecture guidance, not specific implementation details for individual plugins

output_examples.input: How do I structure a new plugin with commands and hooks?
output: A Claude Code plugin follows this structure:
â€¢ commands/ - Slash command definitions (.md files)

The manifest defines plugin metadata and can specify custom paths. Commands and hooks auto-discover from their directories. Hooks can run bash scripts in response to events like PreToolUse or PostToolUse.

best_practices: Use kebab-case for all directory names, file names, and component names for consistency across platforms.
Keep the plugin.json manifest lean and rely on auto-discovery for standard component directories.
Always use ${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT} instead of hardcoded absolute paths to make your plugin portable.
anti_patterns: Hardcoding absolute paths like /Users/name/plugins/ - this breaks portability across different systems.
Nesting component directories inside .claude-plugin/ - components must be at the plugin root level.
Skipping the plugin.json manifest or placing it in the wrong location - Claude Code requires it in .claude-plugin/

faq.question: What is the minimum required for a Claude Code plugin?
faq.answer: A minimal plugin needs only a .claude-plugin/plugin.json with a name field, and at least one component like a command in the commands/ directory.

faq.question: Where should I place the plugin.json file?
faq.answer: The plugin.json must be in a .claude-plugin directory at your plugin root. Components like commands, agents, and skills go at the root level, not inside .claude-plugin.

faq.question: How do I use portable paths in my plugin?
faq.answer: Use ${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT} as a placeholder for your plugin installation directory. This environment variable is set automatically and works across all platforms.

faq.question: What components can a plugin contain?
faq.answer: Plugins can include commands (slash commands), agents (subagent definitions), skills (auto-activating capabilities), hooks (event handlers), MCP servers, and helper scripts.

faq.question: How does auto-discovery work?
faq.answer: Claude Code automatically finds components by scanning standard directories: commands/, agents/, skills/, and loading hooks.json. No manual registration required for standard layouts.

faq.question: Can I use custom paths for components?
faq.answer: Yes, you can specify custom paths in plugin.json. These supplement rather than replace default directories. Custom paths must start with ./ and be relative to the plugin root.
